uncertainty.description: Stores the uncertainty on the parent \element{double}.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

double.description: Stores a double-precision quantity along with a unit, optional label and uncertainty
double.name: double

description: The \element{integer} physical quantity is used to store quantities that can only be integers.
It is similar to the \element{double}, except that the value must be an integer
(e.g. value=`1' rather than value=`1.0').
Uncertainties are also treated differently: rather than an \element{uncertainty} node,
tentative assignments are indicated by storing each possible assignment along with a likelihood.
integer.name: integer

description: The \element{fraction} physical quantity is used to store values that can only be
integers or fractions.  It is nearly identical to the \element{integer},
but the value in this case may either be an integer or a ratio of integers separated
by the `/' character, as in `3/2'.  Values like `1.5' are not allowed.
fraction.name: fraction

value.description: contains a string composed of printable ascii characters (e.g., `stable').
value.name: value

string.description:
The \element{string} physical quantity is used to store quantities that cannot be represented numerically. The main examples are half-lives for
stable particles, which are best represented as the string `stable'.
string.name: string

href.description: The URL or xpath-like string pointing to the referred-to element
href.name: href

description: Used to explicitly link to another part of the GNDS document (or an external document).
For example, if both axis grids in a \elemlink{gridded2d}
container are identical, the \element{link} can be used rather than repeating the grid values.
link.name: link

confidenceIntervals.description: Stores a list of intervals along with the confidence that the `true value' lies within each interval.
confidenceIntervals.name: confidenceIntervals

pdf.description: Stores a probability distribution as a 1-dimensional function.
pdf.name: pdf

description: Store the uncertainty for a 1-dimensional function.
Uncertainties are assumed to be normally distributed. If uncertainties are correlated,
use the \element{covariance} option instead.
XYs1d.name: XYs1d

description: Stores uncertainties for each coefficient in a polynomial expansion.
Uncertainties are assumed to be normally distributed. If coefficients are correlated,
use the \element{covariance} option instead.
polynomial1d.name: polynomial1d

description: Stores a covariance matrix (or a link to a covariance matrix),
usually for a 1-dimensional function.
covariance.name: covariance

description: Stores a list of covariance matrices (or a list of links to covariance matrices).
This option is generally used for higher-dimensional functions. For example,
if an angular distribution $P(\mu|E)$ is stored as an energy-dependent list of
\element{Legendre} expansions, the full covariance may be decomposed into energy-dependent
covariance matrices for each combination of $L_i$ and $L_j$. The \element{listOfCovariances}
lists all of these covariances.
listOfCovariances.name: listOfCovariances

uncertainty.description: Stores the uncertainty for a scalar quantity or a functional data container.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

covariance.description: Covariance matrix (or link to a covariance matrix).
covariance.name: covariance

description: Stores a list of covariance matrices (or a list of links to covariance matrices).
This option is generally used for higher-dimensional functions. For example,
if an angular distribution $P(\mu|E)$ is stored as an energy-dependent list of
\element{Legendre} expansions, the full covariance may be decomposed into energy-dependent
covariance matrices for each combination of $L_i$ and $L_j$. The \element{listOfCovariances}
lists all of these covariances.
listOfCovariances.name: listOfCovariances

label.description: Unique label for this covariance (required if it resides in a \elemlink{listOfCovariances}).
label.name: label

href.description: The URL or xpath-like string pointing to the referred-to element. Often points to a covariance inside the \elemlink{covarianceSuite}.
href.name: href

description: Stores a covariance matrix (or a link to a covariance matrix),
usually for a 1-dimensional function.
covariance.name: covariance

description: Used to store the standard deviation of a standard Gaussian uncertainty distribution. The mean value and unit are
stored higher up in the hierarchy, for example in the parent \element{double} node.
standard.name: standard

description: Used to store the standard deviation $\sigma$ of a log-normal uncertainty distribution, $X = e^{\mu + \sigma Z}$. The mean value and unit are
stored higher up in the hierarchy, for example in the parent \element{double} or \element{averageEnergy} node.
logNormal.name: logNormal

description: Stores a list of intervals along with the confidence that the `true value' lies within each interval. The mean value and unit are
stored higher up in the hierarchy, for example in the parent \element{double} or \element{averageEnergy} node.
confidenceIntervals.name: confidenceIntervals

confidence.description: A value between 0 and 1, indicating how confident the evaluator is that the `true' value lies between mean - lower and mean + upper.
confidence.name: confidence

lower.description: Value to subtract from the mean to obtain the lower limit for this interval.
lower.name: lower

upper.description: Value to add to the mean to obtain the upper limit for this interval.
upper.name: upper

interval.description: Stores a list of intervals along with the confidence that the `true value' lies within each interval.
interval.name: interval

pdf.description: Stores an explicit probability distribution for the parent quantity.
pdf.name: pdf

href.description: A the URL, in xpath syntax, of another \element{axes} element
href.name: href

axis.description: This node stores an \element{index}, \element{label} and \element{unit} for an axis.
axis.name: axis

grid.description: Stores a list of boundaries or points along this axis, e.g. to define group boundaries for grouped data.
grid.name: grid

description: Many of the data containers represent functions that have independent and dependent axes.
The \element{axes} node provides a way to assign a label and unit to each axis.
If an \element{axes} node is present, each independent and dependent axis must have an
\element{axis} or \element{grid} node.
The \element{axis} or \element{grid} nodes are indexed 0 to $n$ where $n$ is the number of independent axes.
For the function $x_0(x_n, ..., x_1)$, index 0 is for dependent axis $x_0$, 1 is for
independent axis $x_1$, ... and $n$ is for the independent axis $x_n$.
Note: Two types of axes nodes are allowed:
\begin{itemize}
\item One type gives an xlink to another axes node
\item The other lists the axes explicitly.
\end{itemize}
axes.name: axes

description: An integer that indicates which independent/dependent axis this \element{axis}
node belongs to as defined in Section~\ref{format:gpdc:axes}.
index.name: index

axis.description: This node stores an \element{index}, \element{label} and \element{unit} for an axis.
axis.name: axis

description: An integer that indicates which independent/dependent axis this \element{grid}
node belongs to.
index.name: index

description: Defines the interpolation to be used between consecutive domain points along this axis.
Note, this attribute is required when \element{style} is \attr{points} or \attr{boundaries} and
interpolation is other than \attr{lin-lin}.
interpolation.name: interpolation

description: A string denoting the type of grid associated with this axis.   Allowed values are `none', `points',
`boundaries' and `parameters'.
style.name: style

values.description: List of values defining the grid.
values.name: values

link.description: Link to a list of values defining the grid.
link.name: link

description: The \element{grid} node is like the \element{axis} but adds a list of values that the function is evaluated at for the
independent axis defined by the  \element{grid}. The \element{grid} has the same three attributes (\element{index},
\element{label}, and \element{unit}) as the \element{axis} node and adds the attributes \element{style}
and \element{interpolation}. In addition, the \element{grid} node has a \element{values} child node
that contains the list of values the function is evaluated at or parameters the function is specified at as
indicated by the \element{style} attribute.
grid.name: grid

description: Specifies the type of data
in the body (e.g., Integer32, Float64).  Only one type of data can be stored
in each instance of a values node.
valueType.name: valueType

start.description: For start=``N'', the first N values are zero and are not stored.
start.name: start

description: The total number of data values including leading and trailing zero
values that are not stored.  This attribute should only be used when
the sum of \attr{start} and the number of listed values do not
add to the total number of data values.   This should only happen when there are trailing zeros not
listed in the Body text.
length.name: length

values.bodyText: Contains a space-delimited ordered list of data for the parent node.
description: Data containers have meta-data and data. In most cases the data have one common piece of meta-data,
which is the \element{type} of data.  For, this reason, many of the containers
store their data in a \element{values} node where, if needed, \element{type} is stored.
This node also allows for compressing leading and trailing zero data. If the \element{start} attribute
is defined, it specifies the first non-zero data value. If the sum of the \element{start}
and the number of data values is less than the value of the \element{length} attribute, then the
the \element{length} value represents the total number of data values including the
non-specified leading and trailing zeros.
All data in this node must be of the same type and separated by one or more white spaces.
values.name: values

description: a comma-separated list of integers representing the length of
the array along each dimension. The integer type is Integer32.
shape.name: shape

description: A flag indicating whether a sparse storage scheme is being used,
and if so which scheme is used.  Allowed value is either
`none', `diagonal', `flattened' or `embedded'.  Projects can also define their own
compression schemes.
compression.name: compression

description: Allows for storing values in only
the upper- or lower-diagonal hyper-triangle. Allowed values are `none', `lower' and `upper'.
If \attrval{permutation} is `none', non-stored values are zero.
Otherwise, they are determine by the \attrval{permutation} attribute.
symmetry.name: symmetry

description: If \attrval{symmetry} is other then `none',
this attribute specifies whether the permutation of two indices is +1 or -1. Allowed
values are `none', `+1' and `-1'.
permutation.name: permutation

description: Indicates whether the data are stored in row-major
or column-major order (i.e., whether the last or first index is varying the fastest).
Allowed values are `row-major' or `column-major',
storageOrder.name: storageOrder

description: Required if this array is nested inside an \attrval{embedded} array; not allowed otherwise;
Gives the starting indices for a sub-array nested inside an array that uses \attrval{embedded} compression.
A comma-separated list of integers equal in dimension to the parent array. The integer type is Integer32.,
offset.name: offset

description: Containers holding the array values. The number of \element{values} nodes depends on the \attr{compression}
attribute. For compression of `embedded', `none', or `flattened' the number of \element{values}
nodes are 0, 1, or 3 respectively. For `diagonal' compression, either 1 or 2 \element{values} nodes may be present.
values.name: values

description: Containers holding sub-arrays embedded in a larger array. The number of \element{array} nodes depends on the
\attr{compression} attribute. For compression of `embedded', 0 or more are allowed. For compression of `none',
`diagonal' or `flattened' no \element{array} nodes are allowed.
array.name: array

description: An array consists of attributes indicating the dimension, compression strategy, etc. and
a list of one or more \element{values} nodes that depend on the value of the \attr{compression} attribute.
The \attr{label} attribute of each \element{values} node designates the type of data stored in
that node. For the \element{values} node containing the data of the array, no label shall
be specified. The allowed \textbf{values} nodes for different compressions are:
\begin{description}
\item[compression=`none':] in this case the array only contains a single \element{values} node that
contains the array data. The \attr{label} attribute of the \element{values} node shall
not be used. The number of data in  the \element{values} node
depends on the array shape and the values of the \attr{symmetry} and \attr{storageOrder} attributes.
\item[compression=`diagonal':] if all off-diagonal nodes are zero, then the
diagonal array only needs to contain a \element{values} node,
with size = N (the smallest array dimension).
If some off-diagonal nodes are included, then the array contains two \element{values}
nodes. One node has label=``startingIndices'' and contains the starting indices. The
other node contains the array data and its \attr{label} attribute must
not be used.
\item[compression=`flattened':] In this case the array contains three \element{values} nodes.
One node contains a list of starting indices in the flattened array and has \attr{label}=``starts''. Another node
contains the number of values given after each `start' and has \attr{label}=``lengths''.
The third node contains the array data and its \attr{label} attribute shall
not be used.  The \attr{starts} and \attr{lengths} both shall have data
type Integer32, and must have the same size.
\item[compression=`embedded':] contains 0 or more child \element{array} nodes.
Each child array shall have the same data type as the parent array,
must have an \attr{offset} attribute, and must obey size restrictions as described in
Section~\ref{embeddeddef}.
\end{description}
array.name: array

columns.description: The number of columns of the table.
columns.name: columns

rows.description: The number of rows of the table.
rows.name: rows

storageOrder.description: Allowed value is one of `row-major' and `column-major'
storageOrder.name: storageOrder

columnHeaders.description: Contains a list of N `header' nodes where N is the number of columns.
columnHeaders.name: columnHeaders

data.description: The data for the table, consisting of M $\times$ N cells.
data.name: data

column.description: Container which holds the name, units, etc. describing a column of data.
column.name: column

columnHeaders.description: Contains a list of N `header' nodes where N is the number of columns.
columnHeaders.name: columnHeaders

index.description: An integer value in the range 0 to (N-1) that represents the order of the column.
index.name: index

name.description: A string representing the name of the column.
name.name: name

unit.description: The unit of the data in the column.
unit.name: unit

types.description: Comma separated list of valid GNDS types denoting what types of elements are allowed in each cell in the column.
types.name: types

description: Container which holds the attributes that describe a column of data including the name, units, etc.
column.name: column

description: Valid options are ``whiteSpace'', ``,'',
``td'', ``tr'' or ``tc''. The standard rules for ``whiteSpace'' and ``comma'' separators
apply. The other separator options are described below.
sep.name: sep

bodyText: The layout of the table data depends on the values of the \attr{storageOrder} and \attr{sep} attributes.
\begin{description}
\item[sep=`whiteSpace' or `,']
In this case the table has no child node, and the body of the table consists of a
\textbf{sep}-separated list containing M $\times$ N values. The order of data depends on the \attr{storageOrder}.
This option can only be used if all data in the table are numeric types.
\item[sep=`td']
In this case every cell in the table is explicitly contained inside `' and `' (or `',
to indicate an empty cell). The order of data depends on the \attr{storageOrder}. This option can handle
multiple data types, but if only a few cells contain non-numeric data the following two options may
be more concise.
\item[storageOrder=`row-major', sep=`tr']
In this case each row of the table is stored inside `<tr sep=``...''>' and `</tr>'. Each row can define
its own separator, which may be `whiteSpace' (the default), `td' or `,'. Any row containing non-numeric
data must have `sep=``td'''.
\item[storageOrder=`column-major', sep=`tc']
In this case each column of the table is stored inside `<tc sep=``...''>' and `</tc>'.
Each column can define its own separator, which may be `whiteSpace' (the default),
`td' or `,'. Any column containing non-numeric data must have `sep=``td'''.  This storage
is recommended whenever some columns contain only numeric data while
others contain mixed data types, since it helps reduce the size of the numeric columns.
\end{description}
data.description: The data for the table, consisting of M $\times$ N cells.
data.name: data

index.description: Integer index, used when the \element{XYs1d} appears inside a \element{regions1d}.
index.name: index

interpolation.description: The rule for interpolating $y$ along the $x$ axis.
interpolation.name: interpolation

label.description: Unique label. When the \element{XYs1d} appears as a form, the label indicates the associated style.
label.name: label

outerDomainValue.description: When an XYs1d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the outerDomainValue corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

axes.description: The \element{axes} element describing the $x$ and $y$ directions.
axes.name: axes

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this one-dimensional function.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

values.description: Contains the list of the $n$ pairs of $x_i, y_i$ as the list $x_0\ y_0\ x_1\ y_1\ ...\ x_{n-1}\ y_{n-1}$.
values.name: values

description: This node stores a single-valued function $x_0(x_1)$ (i.e., $y(x)$) as a tabulated list of $(x_i,y_i)$ pairs with $x_i < x_{i+1}$.
It may appear on its own (i.e. when storing an energy-dependent cross section or multiplicity), or it may appear inside
of another functional data container such as \element{regions1d} or \element{XYs2d}.
XYs1d.name: XYs1d

interpolation.description: The rule for interpolating $y$ rule along the $x$ axis.
interpolation.name: interpolation

label.description: Unique label. When the \element{Ys1d} appears as a form, the label indicates the associated style.
label.name: label

axes.description: The \element{axes} element describing the $x$ and $y$ directions.
axes.name: axes

description: This node stores a tabulated representation of the single-valued function $x_0(x_1)$. This is like the
\element{XYs1d} node (see Section~\ref{format:gpdc:XYs1d}) except that the independent axis must be a
\element{grid} node (see Section~\ref{format:gpdc:grid}) that either stores a list of $x_i$ values or links to another grid that stores the list.
This node is useful when many tabulated $x_0(x_1)$'s contain the same $x_i$ points. Only one of the \element{Ys1d} node
needs to store the $x_i$ values and the others can link to it, allowing for reduced redundancy and storage.
The $x_i$ values must statisfy $x_i < x_{i+1}$.  The $y_i$ are stored in the \element{values} child node.
Ys1d.name: Ys1d

outerDomainValue.description: When a Legendre series appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the outerDomainValue corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

description: Used if the first \attr{lowerIndex} coefficients are all zero. The upperIndex is equal to lowerIndex plus the number of coefficients
in the \element{values} node, so it is not stored.
lowerIndex.name: lowerIndex

domainMin.description: $y(x_1)$ is only valid (i.e., defined) over the domain \attr{domainMin} $\le x_1 \le$ \attr{domainMax}.  \attr{domainMin} must be less than or equal to \attr{domainMax}.
domainMin.name: domainMin

description: The specifications of the \element{values} node are given in Section~\ref{format:gpdc:values}.
The numeric values are the coefficients $C_i$ listed by consecutive order $i$ starting with \attr{lowerIndex}.
values.name: values

outerDomainValue.description: When a polynomial1d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the outerDomainValue corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

description: Used if the first \attr{lowerIndex} coefficients are all zero. The upperIndex is equal to lowerIndex plus the number of coefficients
in the \element{values} node, so it is not stored.
lowerIndex.name: lowerIndex

domainMin.description: $y(x_1)$ is only valid (i.e., defined) over the domain \attr{domainMin} $\le x_1 \le$ \attr{domainMax}.  \attr{domainMin} must be less than or equal to \attr{domainMax}.
domainMin.name: domainMin

axes.description: The \element{axes} element describing the $x$ and $y$ directions.
axes.name: axes

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this one-dimensional function.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

description: The specifications of the \element{values} node are given in Section~\ref{format:gpdc:values}.
The numeric values are the coefficients $C_i$ listed by consecutive order $i$ starting with lowerIndex.
values.name: values

outerDomainValue.description: When a constant1d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the outerDomainValue corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

domainMin.description: $y(x_1)$ is only valid (i.e., defined) over the domain \attr{domainMin} $\le x_1 \le$ \attr{domainMax}.  \attr{domainMin} must be less than or equal to \attr{domainMax}.
domainMin.name: domainMin

axes.description: The \element{axes} element describing the $x$ and $y$ directions.
axes.name: axes

constant1d.description: Describes a constant one-dimensional function, $f(x) = C$.
constant1d.name: constant1d

outerDomainValue.description: When the xs\_pdf\_cdf1d container appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the outerDomainValue corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

xs.description: Defines the common list of $x$ values for the pdf and cdf.
xs.name: xs

pdf.description: Stores the pdf evaluated at each corresponding $x$ value.
pdf.name: pdf

cdf.description: Stores the cdf evaluated at each corresponding $x$ value.
cdf.name: cdf

description: For Monte-Carlo sampling it is often useful to store both the probability density (pdf) and cumulative probability density (cdf)
on the same grid. The sampling routine can then draw a random number in the range [0,1), do a bisection search through the cdf
to determine which interval the random number lies in, and then use the pdf to sample within that interval. The \element{xs\_pdf\_cdf1d}
container provides a way to store these three related quantities together. The number of values in the \element{xs}, \element{pdf}
and \element{cdf} must be the same.
xs_pdf_cdf1d.name: xs_pdf_cdf1d

xs_in_xs_pdf_cdf1d.description: Stores the common list of $x$ values for use in an \element{xs\_pdf\_cdf1d}.
xs_in_xs_pdf_cdf1d.name: xs

pdf_in_xs_pdf_cdf1d.description: Stores the value of the pdf at each $x$ in an \element{xs\_pdf\_cdf1d}.
pdf_in_xs_pdf_cdf1d.name: pdf_in_xs_pdf_cdf1d

cdf_in_xs_pdf_cdf1d.description: Stores the value of the cdf at each $x$ in an \element{xs\_pdf\_cdf1d}.
cdf_in_xs_pdf_cdf1d.name: cdf

index.description: Integer index, required when the \element{XYs2d} appears inside a \element{regions2d}.
index.name: index

interpolation.description: The rule for interpolating $x_0$ along the $x_2$ axis.
interpolation.name: interpolation

outerDomainValue.description: When an XYs2d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the outerDomainValue corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

function1ds.description: Contains the list of 1-dimensional functions $x_0(x_1)$ that represent $x_0(x_2, x_1)$ at various points along $x_2$.
function1ds.name: function1ds

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this two-dimensional function.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

description: This node stores a 2-dimensional function $x_0(x_2, x_1)$ as a list of 1-dimensional functions at various $x_2$ values. Each 1-dimensional
function stores its $x_2$ point in its \attr{value} attribute. The attributes \attr{interpolation} and \attr{interpolationQualifier}
instruct how to interpolate $x_2$ and $x_0$ between two adjacent 1-dimensional functions.
XYs2d.name: XYs2d

functional.description: Any valid 1-dimensional function that is consistent with the quantity being represented.
functional.name: functional

function1ds.description: This node stores a list of 1-dimensional functions.
function1ds.name: function1ds

interpolation.description: The rule for interpolating $x_0$ along the $x_3$ axis.
interpolation.name: interpolation

function2ds.description: Contains the list of 2-dimensional functions that represent $x_0(x_3, x_2, x_1)$ at various points along $x_3$ as a $x_0(x_2, x_1)$ functions.
function2ds.name: function2ds

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this three-dimensional function.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

description: This node stores a 3-dimensional function $x_0(x_3, x_2, x_1)$ as a list of 2-dimensional functions at various $x_3$ values. Each 2-dimensional
function stores its $x_3$ point in its \attr{value} attribute. The attributes \attr{interpolation} and \attr{interpolationQualifier}
instruct how to interpolate $x_3$ and $x_0$ between two adjacent 2-dimensional functions.
XYs3d.name: XYs3d

functional.description: Any valid 2-dimensional function that is consistent with the quantity being represented.
functional.name: functional

function2ds.description: This node stores a list of 2-dimensional functions.
function2ds.name: function2ds

outerDomainValue.description: When an \element{regions1d} appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the \attr{outerDomainValue} corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

description: Contains the list of 1-dimensional functions that represent $x_0(x_1)$. The upper $x_1$ value for a function
in the list must be equal to the lower $x_1$ value for the next function in the list.
function1ds.name: function1ds

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this one-dimensional function.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

outerDomainValue.description: When a regions2d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the outerDomainValue corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

description: Contains the list of 2-dimensional functions that represent $x_0(x_2, x_1)$. The upper $x_2$ value for a function
in the list must be equal to the lower $x_2$ value for the next function in the list.
function2ds.name: function2ds

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this two-dimensional function.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

outerDomainValue.description: When a regions3d appears inside a higher-dimensional container, the outerDomainValue corresponds to the next higher dimension.
outerDomainValue.name: outerDomainValue

description: Contains the list of 3-dimensional functions that represent $x_0(x_3, x_2, x_1)$. The upper $x_3$ value for a function
in the list must be equal to the lower $x_3$ value for the next function in the list.
function3ds.name: function3ds

uncertainty.description: Uncertainty and/or covariance for this three-dimensional function.
uncertainty.name: uncertainty

functional.description: Any valid 3-dimensional function that is consistent with the quantity being represented.
functional.name: functional

function3ds.description: This node stores a list of 3-dimensional functions.
function3ds.name: function3ds

gridded1d.description: A one-dimensional function defined on a grid or set of groups.
gridded1d.name: gridded1d

gridded2d.description: A two-dimensional function defined on a grid or set of groups.
gridded2d.name: gridded2d

gridded3d.description: A three-dimensional function defined on a grid or set of groups.
gridded3d.name: gridded3d
